thinking.disposable_income: South Chicago has relatively low income levels with median income of $43,936 and 55.6% households earning less than $50,000. About 30.9% earn less than $25,000, indicating limited disposable income for many residents
thinking.discretionary_consumption: Given the low income levels, residents have limited discretionary spending capacity. Higher sales taxes or transportation costs would significantly impact household budgets and reduce spending on other essential needs
thinking.accessibility: 31.6% of households have no vehicle, and 23.7% rely on transit for commuting. While 58.2% drive alone, the high proportion of transit-dependent residents suggests need for affordable and efficient public transit
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritized proposals with lower sales tax (0.5%) to minimize impact on limited discretionary income. 2. Favored lower transit fares ($0.75-$1.25) to help transit-dependent residents. 3. Supported moderate driving fees ($0.50-$1.00) to improve transit service while not overly burdening drivers. 4. Balanced travel time improvements with cost burden on low-income residents. 5. Considered high proportion of both transit users and drivers in the community
